nodes.label: Photosynthetically Active Radiation (PAR)
nodes.description: Traditional definition includes photons from 400 to 700 nm, excluding far-red photons.

nodes.label: Far-red photons
nodes.description: Photons in the range of 701â€“750 nm that significantly contribute to photosynthesis, especially in shaded environments.

nodes.label: Leaf Gross Photosynthesis
nodes.description: Total photosynthesis occurring in leaves, measured as a percentage contribution from far-red photons.

nodes.label: Photosystem II (PSII)
nodes.description: A protein complex in plants that plays a crucial role in the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis.

nodes.label: Photosystem I (PSI)
nodes.description: A protein complex that absorbs light and drives the production of NADPH in the light-dependent reactions.

nodes.label: Sunlit Conditions
nodes.description: Conditions where plants receive direct sunlight, allowing for higher photosynthetic rates.

nodes.label: Deep Shade
nodes.description: Conditions where plants receive minimal light, impacting photosynthetic efficiency.

nodes.label: Photosynthetic Efficiency
nodes.description: The effectiveness of plants in converting light energy into chemical energy during photosynthesis.

nodes.label: Synergistic Interactions
nodes.description: Interactions between far-red and shorter-wavelength photons that enhance overall photosynthetic rates.

nodes.label: Carbon Cycling
nodes.description: The process by which carbon is exchanged among the biosphere, atmosphere, oceans, and geosphere, influenced by photosynthesis.

nodes.label: Climate Change Impacts
nodes.description: Effects of climate change on ecosystems, including alterations in photosynthetic processes due to changing light conditions.

nodes.label: Canopy Environments
nodes.description: The upper layer of a forest where light availability and photosynthetic activity can vary significantly.

nodes.label: Experimental Conditions
nodes.description: Conditions under which the study was conducted, including the use of filters to isolate far-red photons.

nodes.label: Photosynthetic Models
nodes.description: Mathematical representations of photosynthesis that may underestimate actual rates by excluding far-red photons.

nodes.label: Crop Improvement
nodes.description: Strategies aimed at enhancing crop yield and resilience, influenced by understanding of photosynthesis.

nodes.label: Ecosystem Productivity
nodes.description: The rate at which energy is converted by photosynthetic and chemosynthetic autotrophs to organic substances.

nodes.label: Global Carbon Cycle
nodes.description: The movement of carbon through the Earth's systems, significantly influenced by photosynthesis.

nodes.label: Photosynthetic Potential
nodes.description: The maximum capacity of plants to perform photosynthesis under optimal conditions, including far-red light.

nodes.label: Incident Photons
nodes.description: Photons that reach the plant surface, with far-red photons constituting over 50% in shaded environments.

nodes.label: Photosynthetic Rate Enhancement
nodes.description: Increase in photosynthetic rates due to the presence of far-red photons, particularly in shaded conditions.

edges.label: Far-red photons are excluded from traditional PAR definition
Far-red photons contribute to leaf gross photosynthesis
Leaf gross photosynthesis is higher in sunlit conditions
Leaf gross photosynthesis is lower in deep shade
PSII efficiency is enhanced by far-red photons
Photosynthesis is affected by climate change impacts
Canopy environments affect leaf gross photosynthesis
Experimental conditions included filters for far-red photons
Understanding photosynthesis aids in crop improvement
Ecosystem productivity is driven by photosynthesis
Photosynthesis is a key component of the global carbon cycle
Incident photons include far-red photons in shaded environments
